item.title: Social media & actually owning what you publish
item.description:
Ah, social media. The thing that (theoretically) democratized everyone‚Äôs voice. That allowed two-way communication impossible to do beforehand if you weren‚Äôt in a niche circle.

The thing that cost you the ownership of your own content.

Do you remember in the 90s, when everyone active on the web had their own blog? Even those that didn‚Äôt self-host and used platforms like Blogger or Wordpress (or Movable Type), you wrote under your username (me.site.com) and eventually were able to point your own domains there. This sounds like a simple thing, but it kept you in control of you what you published. If you‚Äôd wanted to change platforms‚Äîanything from you having an issue with the way the platform ran, to you were just bored‚Äîyou moved your domain over and your readers just continued to find you, or follow your owned RSS feed in a reader.

Then came the Facebook era. The Twitter era. Instagram. Medium. Platforms that broke through a significant problem with traditional blogs: writing in silos. Social media platforms redefined engagement and discovery of other creators, bringing anyone and everyone into one space. People could just follow you and you could share your links seamlessly.

And then you stopped writing on the blog altogether. You just posted on Facebook, and Twitter, and Instagram. The platforms made posting easier and easier, and starting silo‚Äôing alternative platforms. Like when Instagram removed Twitter card support & Twitter stopped showing you previews of Instagram photos. Twitter eventually bought out and integrated their own photo services. Facebook doesn‚Äôt let you embed content outside of the platform either; you either link it and live with it, or upload the video separately to Facebook. And therein lies another part of the problem. They want to keep you in, make it harder for you to use alternatives for even a part of the services, either buying out or copying feature sets.

A few years ago, a couple of guys went about building a blogging platform designed to take on the complications of Wordpress and provide sturdy posting & inherent collaboration. It was called Posterous and I migrated almost instantly. Spoiler alert: Twitter bought out Posterous and ‚Ä¶. shut down the platform.

So when Twitter or Instagram decides to shut down your account, censor you, or otherwise prevent you from accessing it or taking your username away, there‚Äôs ‚Ä¶ nothing you can do about it. Facebook‚Äôs been selling everything about you for years, and Twitter is equally guilty. Twitter is also horrendous about handling harassment, spam and hate. Rumors about Twitter arbitrarily ‚Äòshadow banning‚Äô users ‚Äî stopping their tweets from showing up in timelines of followers for a while ‚Äî¬†continue.

In unrelated news, Medium recently & quietly ended the ability to map your domain to Medium.

If any of this comes as news to you, that‚Äôs a good thing.

Enter the Open Web. The Web as it should have been built. As a series of integrated platforms allowing anyone to everyone to own their content, to retain flexibility to use services they wanted. Platforms that let you brand your content to you, and don‚Äôt arbitrarily decide whether your account is deemed worthy to be verified. That allows you to Publish on your Own Site & Syndicate Elsewhere (POSSE). And those that allow you to take your data out in a format compatable to some standard when you want to leave. A group of talented people have been hard at work at developing both the standards & principles over at IndieWeb.org and I recommend you check it out.

This is why I‚Äôve migrated all of my writing over to micro.blog a few months ago. Today I publish on my own blog that I own and pay for, push to services like Twitter and Medium, and can continue conversations there, as well as within the Micro.blog timeline of connected blogs. Should anything happen with some of these services, I still have my original posts. A full backup of my blog, with individual posts, CSS etc sits in GitHub pages as a failsafe with Micro.blog itself, or in case I want out. None of this required any complicated setup, they‚Äôre features of the platform and its adherence to the IndieWeb Principles.

I‚Äôll be elaborating more about ownership & the IndieWeb as time passes, but I wanted to share some of my motivations and why I‚Äôve been feeling so strongly about these platforms recently. You don‚Äôt have to do any of this, but I do think it‚Äôs time you‚Äîand everyone‚Äîthinks about it: where you are posting, do you actually own your content, and are you in an environment that encourages ownership, fosters conversation & responsibility vs just a cacophony of echo chambers, spam, hate & likes.

item.title: Building the Micro.blog ecosystem
item.description:
Manton Reece:

I think a goal for us with Micro.blog should be that third-party developers get access to the same basic tools that we use to build our own apps. Rate-limits should be the same for an app like Icro as they are for the official Micro.blog app, for example.

For the last few weeks, I‚Äôve been thinking about blogging and content, and how the breakup of traditional ‚Äòblogs‚Äô have cost us, the netizens, a whole lot.

The more time passes, the more I appreciate the philosophy that sits behind Micro.blog. Every decision won‚Äôt be perfect and/or popular, but it is good to see that the driving principles of it all are rooted in the right place. Manton‚Äôs been extremely open and communicative about it, so I hope that part scales as this gets bigger. With the way Twitter is handling third-party apps that built the platform, the timing is perfect too.

Oh, and:

(To be clear, we‚Äôd offer this for free. Our business is blog hosting.)

I‚Äôm glad to see Micro.blog‚Äôs monetary stream is both clear upfront and doesn‚Äôt require surrendering user privacy.

item.title: What Twitter was, and what it is now
item.description:
Jean MacDonald:

I have several friends in ‚Äúreal life‚Äù who started as Twitter buddies. But over the years, Twitter has become something I don‚Äôt recognize anymore, a place where hate and intolerance and crass commercialism have found a welcoming home.

As a side note, a nice insight into understanding micro.blog as a Twitter user‚Äîhow they‚Äôre same in some ways, and how they‚Äôre different.

Her Twitter experience though is not far away from mine; some of my closest friendships & collaborations have their origins on the network, but ‚Ä¶ here we are now.

Jean doesn‚Äôt get into this much but a long-standing problem with Twitter is how they‚Äôve stifled third party development, over, over and over again. I mean, even a service like LinkedIn doesn‚Äôt‚Äîwell, can‚Äôt‚Äîreally integrate with Twitter.

The ‚Äòphilosophy‚Äô of increasingly closing off the network to the outside world or the open Web at large has been seeping into other aspects of Twitter‚Äôs culture as an organization & a platform. The last few real Twitter apps are now bending under this weight.

Considering Facebook isn‚Äôt in a particularly great place currently either, hello to an free-er, open-er Web. And hello, Micro.blog.

What is this life if, full of care,

We have no time to stand and stare.

Someday, maybe. Not today. #2018

item.title: Massaging egos #facebook
item.description:
Zeynep Tufekci, writing for WIRED:

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs Time to Make Our Privacy Tools Easier to Find‚Äù, the company announced without a hint of irony‚Äîor any other kind of hint‚Äîthat Zuckerberg had promised to do just that in the ‚Äúcoming few weeks‚Äù eight full years ago. On the company blog, Facebook‚Äôs chief privacy editor wrote that instead of being ‚Äúspread across nearly 20 different screens‚Äù (why were they ever spread all over the place?), the controls would now finally be in one place.

It‚Äôs a long read but a great piece that highlights the right things. Any other company would have lost trust years ago but Facebook continues to enjoy the advantage of the ‚Äògravity‚Äô effect of having 2 billion users.

My co-host Partha made a super important point last week:

These products have been made by the same people who lived with the same sort of theory that [our generation] grew up with [‚Ä¶] they understand the importance of this privacy and they‚Äôve been building on top of this to try and massage the egos of all the newer generations [‚Ä¶] to try and make sure they‚Äôre comfortable about it.

The more I think about this, the more spot-on this is. People who watched‚Äîushered in, even‚Äîthe social media era and understand the privacy implications could have gone about it in two ways: ensure that even those who do not understand this are protected, or help transition the vary ones into being more comfortable about sharing. Facebook has gone the latter way too often that it‚Äôs now part of its core, making it impossible to be anything else.

item.title: Facebook: ‚ÄòEveryone‚Äôs doing it‚Äô
item.description:
Sean Gallagher, writing for Ars Technica:

In response to an email inquiry by Ars about this data gathering, a Facebook spokesperson replied, ‚ÄúThe most important part of apps and services that help you make connections is to make it easy to find the people you want to connect with. So, the first time you sign in on your phone to a messaging or social app, it‚Äôs a widely used practice to begin by uploading your phone contacts.‚Äù

A widely used practice is something Facebook could have taken a stand on, eons ago, and led the industry, rather hiding under its cover.

As much as the headlines about Facebook having a bad week will continue, it‚Äôs amazing how unchecked the whole system was:

If you granted permission to read contacts during Facebook‚Äôs installation on Android a few versions ago‚Äîspecifically before Android 4.1 (Jelly Bean)‚Äîthat permission also granted Facebook access to call and message logs by default. The permission structure was changed in the Android API in version 16. But Android applications could bypass this change if they were written to earlier versions of the API, so Facebook API could continue to gain access to call and SMS data by specifying an earlier Android SDK version. Google deprecated version 4.0 of the Android API in October 2017‚Äîthe point at which the latest call metadata in Facebook users‚Äô data was found.

The issue with such far reaching applications and OS‚Äô is that there aren‚Äôt‚Äîand are unlikely to be anytime soon‚Äîoverarching regulations that can manage these issues. Even if the US or the EU has stringent privacy regulations that will allow them to penalize Facebook‚Äôs entities within their jurisdiction, that‚Äôs as far as they‚Äôd be able to go.

Six months down the road, where will this situation be? Will Facebook brazen it out through via heres-another-setting-under-privacy-settings? That can be the only real indicator.

item.title: Nanima
item.description:
You were a phenomal woman who moved mountains for her children & grandchildren. The way you‚Äôd share stories of your kids growing up ‚Ä¶ almost like a child skipping through a garden in excitement. I learnt this week that maybe I‚Äôve inherited my eyes from you‚Ä¶
Why don‚Äôt I hear your voice say ‚ÄúWho is it, is that you Chirag‚Äù as I walk past the door? Always checking to make sure I‚Äôd eaten. Something that hasn‚Äôt changed since 9th grade incidentally, when I spent 2 months living alone with you & Nanaji. That time though, you just cooked for me the whole time and turned me into a nice little ball. Things I wanted to eat, and things I didn‚Äôt even think of. In many ways, I‚Äôm a product of those 2 months, as much as I am a product of your daugther‚Äôs hard work, something she entirely learnt from you.
You fought hard I know, and I hope it is nothing but peaceful now.
The last time I heard your voice ‚Ä¶ you insisted on speaking to me ‚Ä¶ it was tough to hear you sound like you were giving up. Today, with time, I can reflect on your powerful words ‚Ä¶ and your belief in me through them.
